Award.AwardTitle: Cal Poly Noyce Scholars Program, Phase II

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Education and Human Resources

Award.AbstractNarration: In this Phase II project the PI team and partners at several local school districts: Lucia Mar Unified School District (LMUSD), Santa Maria Bonita School District (SMBSD), and Santa Maria Joint Union High School District (SMJUHSD) are working together to attract high quality Cal Poly mathematics majors into teaching careers and preparing them to be credentialed teachers, committed to teaching in high-needs school districts. The project is providing nine mathematics majors with two-year scholarships to support the final year of their undergraduate studies and their subsequent participation in a one-year credential program. In addition twelve students from the larger group of STEM majors are receiving scholarships to support their participation in the one-year credential program. Scholars from Cal Poly and other Noyce scholarship projects in California also have the opportunity for continued professional development through the Cal Poly summer Noyce scholars workshops. The intellectual merit of this project rests in its focus on the recruitment of exceptional students into a quality teacher preparation program that complements an expanded high-quality professional development experience during the summers for the Noyce scholars. Cal Poly Noyce Scholars are mentored by university faculty and local teachers who challenge them to excel in the classroom and provide them the opportunity to consider relevant educational issues, as part of their formal training to receive a secondary teaching credential. This support continues through attendance at summer workshops as they begin careers as mathematics teachers in high-needs school districts. The broader impact of this project is felt first in its preparation and retention of well-prepared secondary mathematics teachers for high-need school districts. Moreover, the interplay of academic year preparation and summer professional development with cohorts of teachers from the region acts to create a network of Noyce scholars who can encourage their own students to pursue degrees in a STEM discipline.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Our Noyce Scholarship Program funded 49 (23 Phase II) scholars, 48 (23 Phase II) of whom have graduated with a teaching credential as of June 2018. Of these graduates 45 (22 Phase II) are currently teaching in secondary schools and 38 of them have satisfied their teaching requirement. Two scholars have moved on to complete Ph.D. programs in Mathematics Education with one currently working with Dr. Jo Boaler. Over a ten-year period retaining 91.8% of scholars in the teaching profession and motivating two to pursue graduate degrees is an accomplishment to be proud of.

The following list highlights other successes of our scholars and program.

  • Our scholars have regularly attended the regional or national Noyce conferences. One of our scholars was a member of the panel Voices from the Field at the national conference in 2010.
  • The PIs have given 8 presentations at regional or national meetings and have included 5 scholars as part of these presentations.
  • Since the establishment of the Noyce Program, 9.05 Cal Poly undergraduates have completed the credential program on average per year.  In the five years prior to the awards, 5.2 Cal Poly undergraduates completed the credential program on average per year. The Noyce awards have allowed us to retain quality students at Cal Poly for their credential program.
  • At the time of applying for a scholarship, the average GPA of Cal Poly Noyce scholars is 3.25. This strong performance in a rigorous mathematics major is more evidence that the Noyce Scholars Program is attracting high achieving students to the teaching profession.

Besides providing scholarships, a major component of our program was to provide professional development to Noyce scholars from the Western Region in the form of summer workshops for the duration of our program. The steady increase in summer workshop participants culminating with 48 participants in 2016, 52 participants in summer 2017 and 25 in 2018 (only one section was offered due to funding ending) is an indication of the success of the program.  Beyond the increase in participants, the success of the summer workshops is also evidenced in the following summaries provided by our program evaluator that have been consistent throughout the duration of our project.

  • The participants highly valued the opportunity to talk with other scholars in similar positions and especially scholars who were one or two years ahead of them.  They gained valuable resources from each other as well as an honest perspective of the environments they were facing.  Many participants commented on the value of feeling part of a group with common issues. Participants left with close connections to at least one or two other scholars they would be able to contact remotely during the school year.
  • In particular, they appreciated hearing about the unique issues they would face in high need districts, from existing resources and staff to issues specific to this student audience.  Even hearing a few stories and anecdotes appeared to reassure them and raise their confidence levels of what they would be facing.  Hearing those comments in person from practicing teachers and other Noyce scholars appeared to give much weight and credence to the comments.
  • Scholars liked working with teaching a common age range and seeing lessons developed and refined. They also appreciated hearing from recent scholars on their experiences using some of the activities in the classroom and how they managed resources to maintain an active learning environment.  Almost all participants felt more confident in their own teaching after the workshop.
  • Scholars who have benefited from our program through the summer workshops include scholars from Arizona, Texas, Oregon, Washington, Colorado, Nevada, Utah and several other universities from California. Scholars received $800 travel stipend to attend the workshop.

Beyond the specific aspects of the workshop, part of our Phase II evaluation focused on whether the workshops were helping to develop teacher leaders.  We surveyed past Noyce workshop participants and found that 48 of 56 respondents have taken some sort of leadership role in their school or district.  While many of these Noyce scholars have taken multiple leadership roles the most popular are club advisor (23 participants), mentor (23 participants), curriculum development lead (22 participants), coach (19 participants), and department chair (13 participants).  While we can?t point to the workshops directly causing participants to take a leadership role, the large number of participants who have done so and the varied roles they have taken are compelling evidence that, at a minimum, the workshop is providing support for teacher leaders throughout the western United States.
